name: Chicago Community Bond Fund
mission: Chicago Community Bond Fund pays bond for people in Cook County, Illinois. Through a revolving fund, CCBF supports individuals whose communities cannot ...
theoryOfChange: By paying bond, CCBF restores the presumption of innocence and enables recipients to remain free while fighting their cases, while simultaneously advocating for systemic abolition of the money bond system.
zakatClaimEvidence: Organization is in zakat denylist (partners but doesn't collect directly) (Source: https://chicagobond.org/donate/)

score_details.score_summary: Chicago Community Bond Fund shows good impact and moderate alignment. Evidence score may reflect limited reporting capacity, not program weakness.

all_citations.claim: The charity holds a 96.0/100 score and focuses on revolving fund and public education programs.
Total revenue was $751,883 with a program expense ratio of 90.2% and fundraising efficiency of $0.07 per $1 raised.
The organization accepts general donations (sadaqah) to support its mission of paying bond for individuals in Cook County.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial transparency and efficiency, balanced against a lower alignment for donors seeking traditional religious giving pathways.
areas_for_improvement: Limited alignment with specific donor preferences in the Muslim community
Focus on advocacy and capacity building results in a moderate impact score compared to direct service providers

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is rated at 21/50, indicating a moderate fit for general donors but a low fit for those seeking specific religious designations, as the organization is classified as sadaqah-eligible only [3]. The cause is categorized under advocacy, which may appeal to donors interested in systemic legal reform in Cook County [1].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a moderate impact score of 32/50, reflecting its focus on capacity building and systemic advocacy rather than high-volume direct aid [1]. Its financial health is robust, as evidenced by a Charity Navigator score of 96.0/100 and a significant reserve of 47.4 months of working capital [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Chicago Community Bond Fund provides critical financial assistance to individuals in Cook County, Illinois, by paying bond to support those whose communities cannot afford the cost of pretrial release.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 90.2%, ensuring the vast majority of funds go directly to services
Strong financial health with 47.4 months of working capital available
Excellent fundraising efficiency, spending only $0.07 to raise every $1
baseline_narrative.summary: The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) operates a revolving fund and public education programs to assist individuals in the Cook County legal system [1]. In the most recent fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $751,883 while maintaining a high program expense ratio of 90.2% [2]. Supporters can contribute through various methods to help sustain these legal support initiatives [3].

areas_for_improvement.detail: With <cite id="1">47.4 months of working capital</cite>, the organization holds reserves far beyond the industry standard of 6-12 months.
The organization has seen a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of -26.5%</cite>, which may impact future scaling of advocacy efforts.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization currently <cite id="5">meets 0 of the 20 BBB Standards</cite> for Charity Accountability.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains these reserves to ensure the revolving fund can handle large-scale bond requests during legal shifts.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">47.4 months of operating reserves</cite> may indicate under-utilization of available capital.
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="1">excessive accumulation of unrestricted net assets</cite> relative to annual spending.

confidence.notes: Strong financial data available; impact data is narrative-based.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is moderate as the cause is <cite id="1">advocacy-focused</cite> and lacks a specific Muslim-donor engagement strategy.
alignment.improvement: The organization could improve alignment by <cite id="3">clarifying its sadaqah-eligible status</cite> for Muslim donors on its donation pages.

credibility.explanation: CCBF is highly credible, evidenced by a <cite id="1">96.0/100 from Charity Navigator score</cite> and a <cite id="1">90.2% independent board</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To further enhance credibility, the organization could seek to meet all 20 BBB Wise Giving Alliance standards, as they currently <cite id="5">meet 0 out of 20</cite>.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="1">100.0% program ratio</cite>, though <cite id="1">excessive working capital</cite> suggests funds could be deployed more aggressively.
impact.improvement: The organization should <cite id="1">publish consistent beneficiary counts</cite> to allow for a formal cost-per-beneficiary assessment.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Theory of Change documented but limited outcome data

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct payment of bond for individuals

rich_narrative.headline: The Chicago Community Bond Fund provides critical financial assistance to individuals in Cook County, Illinois, by paying bond to support those whose communities cannot afford the cost of pretrial release.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize systemic legal reform and want to support a lean, financially stable organization focused on ending wealth-based pretrial detention.
donor_motivations: Passionate about criminal justice reform in the United States
Value high-efficiency organizations with zero overhead on program spending
Prefer supporting revolving funds where capital is recycled for multiple beneficiaries
giving_considerations: Donations support advocacy and bond payments rather than direct social services
The organization has very high reserves, meaning your gift contributes to long-term sustainability
Focus is hyper-local to the Chicago/Cook County area
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to fulfill Zakat obligations or those looking for international humanitarian relief.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: While the <cite id="1">theory of change is clear</cite>, there is a lack of publicly available, multi-year outcome tracking data regarding beneficiary success post-release.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: CCBF uses a revolving fund to secure pretrial release, which prevents the negative socio-economic consequences of incarceration while advocating for the abolition of cash bond.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that paying bond leads to better legal outcomes and community stability for the individuals served.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While reserves are high, <cite id="4">revenue has declined by 26.5%</cite>, necessitating new support to maintain advocacy programs.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="1">90.2% program expense ratio</cite> and focus on the Cook County jurisdiction.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focus on coordination vs direct payment
similar_organizations.name: National Bail Fund Network

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="1">program expense ratio of 90.2%</cite>, with a fundraising efficiency of only <cite id="1">$0.07 spent to raise every $1</cite>.
CCBF holds a <cite id="1">96/100 rating from Charity Navigator</cite> and has achieved a Gold Seal of Transparency from Candid.
The charity possesses <cite id="1">47.4 months of working capital</cite>, providing significant long-term stability for its revolving fund operations.

strengths_deep_dive: The Chicago Community Bond Fund demonstrates a lean operational model where <cite id="1">90.2% of expenses are directed toward programs</cite>. This efficiency is supported by a <cite id="1">90.2% independent board of directors</cite>, ensuring objective oversight of the organization's <cite id="2">$7.16 million in total assets</cite>. Their revolving fund model is particularly effective, as funds returned when cases conclude are reinvested to support new individuals, creating a self-sustaining cycle of impact. Furthermore, their <cite id="1">fundraising efficiency of $0.07 per $1 raised</cite> is significantly better than industry averages, allowing more capital to remain in the revolving fund.
rich_narrative.summary: The Chicago Community Bond Fund (CCBF) is a specialized legal support organization dedicated to providing financial assistance to individuals in Cook County, Illinois, who are unable to afford pretrial release. The organization operates a <cite id="1">revolving fund to pay bond</cite> for those whose communities lack the financial resources to secure their freedom, directly addressing systemic inequities in the legal system. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $751,883</cite>, reflecting a period of transition as the legal landscape in Illinois shifts. Despite a <cite id="4">3-year revenue CAGR of -26.5%</cite>, CCBF maintains an exceptionally high <cite id="1">program expense ratio of 90.2%</cite> according to recent filings, ensuring that every dollar contributed is utilized for its core mission of bond payment and public education. The organization has earned a <cite id="1">96/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, bolstered by a <cite id="1">perfect 100 score in Culture & Accountability</cite>. Beyond direct financial assistance, CCBF engages in <cite id="3">public education, advocacy, and relationship building</cite> to foster long-term systemic change within the Cook County legal system.
